citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio mexicanus sp. nov., a sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from an upflow anaerobic sludge blanket, UASB reactor treating cheese wastewaters.

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio mexicanus sp. nov.
Desulfovibrio mexicanus (me.xi.ca'nus. N.L. adj. mexicanus mexican, pertaining to Mexico)
Cells stain Gram-negative, are curved (1.7-2.5 x 0.5 μm) and nonspore-formers, exist singly or in chains, and are nonmotile.
Optimum growth occurs at 378C (range 20-40°C) and pH 7.2 (range 6.3-8.2) in a medium containing lactate and thiosulfate.
NaCl is not required for growth.
The strain does not grow in the presence of 20 g/L NaCl.
Sulfate, thiosulfate, elemental sulfur, or sulfite can be used as electron acceptors but not nitrate, nitrite, or fumarate.
The isolate uses formate and H2 (with acetate), pyruvate, Casamino acids, serine, cysteine, and ethanol as electron donors with thiosulfate as an electron acceptor.
Pyruvate, Casamino acids, and serine are fermented.
Thiosulfate is disproportionated to sulfate and sulfide.
The DNA base composition is 66 mol% G+C.
The closest phylogenetic relative is Desulfovibrio aminophilus.
The type strain is strain Lup1T (=DSM 13116).
It was isolated from an UASB digester treating wastewater from a cheese manufacturing factory in Mexico.
